awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Individual and Team Behavior in Strategic Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Economists use game theory (the theory of strategic interactions) to study a wide variety of policy issues such as how to prevent collusion between large firms, how to design auctions for various purposes (e.g. air wave rights), and how to limit dysfunctional phenomena such as bank runs and market panics.  In many of these settings, decisions are made by teams rather than individuals - the board of a large corporation, a congressional committee, etc. - but relatively little is known about how decisions made by teams differ from individuals in strategic interactions. Researchers on this project will conduct carefully designed experiments to  identify how groups agree to cooperate with other groups, the mechanism by which groups perform better (or worse) than individuals at generating more efficient outcomes, and to compare how groups, as opposed to individuals, learn to make choices in related situations from past experience.  Better understanding how teams make decisions, and how these decisions differ from ones made by individuals, will contribute to foundational understanding of game theory. In terms of broader impacts, this research will enable economists to better predict behavior of entities when the decisions of those entities are made by teams rather than individuals.  
 
Psychologists studying repeated prisoner's dilemma games typically find that teams are less cooperative than individuals, referred to as the "discontinuity effect".  Kagel and McGee (2016) fail to find a discontinuity effect across finitely repeated super-games with no communication between teams. Experiments involving multiple plays of repeated PD games with a probabilistic stopping rule will be run with and without communication between opponents to understand why groups seem less cooperative that individuals in some setting but not in others.    A second set of experiment will explore the relative efficacy of communication for teams vs. individuals in reaching the efficient outcome in a coordination game where the efficient equilibrium is quite challenging.  A final set of experiments will examine whether teams and individuals differ in the extent to which they perceive different types of games as similar.

por.por_cntn:
Behavioral and experimental economists have revolutionized economics by showing how outcomes in many economic environments change if more realistic models of human decision making are used, rather than simply assuming that all individuals are fully rational and self-interested. The experimental data that provides the underpinnings for these insights largely is taken from studies where decisions are made by individuals. However, numerous important decisions in economic and policy settings are made by teams. It is difficult to provide managers and policy makers with useful advice if all our evidence comes from individuals. The research funded by this grant focuses on experiments where the decision-making agent is a team of individuals working together. Beyond studying how the choices of individuals and teams differ, dialogues between team members provide a window into the thought processes underlying these decisions.

 

The lead paper funded by the grant illustrates the value of studying team decision making. The prisoner’s dilemma is likely the best-known game in economics, modeling a wide variety of settings where there exists a conflict between what is best for the individual and what is best for the group. If the prisoner’s dilemma is played a single time and all individuals are self-interested, the only rational outcome is for all individuals to behave in a self-interested fashion even though all individuals would be better off if they could somehow cooperate. If the prisoner’s dilemma is repeated indefinitely (i.e., repeated with a random termination date), it is possible to support cooperation through the threat of future punishment. However, repetition is a necessary but not sufficient condition to support cooperation. Experiments have been used to study when cooperation will emerge in reality. Our paper “Using Team Discussions to Understand Behavior in Indefinitely Repeated Prisoner’s Dilemma Games” studies how cooperation changes if the decision making agent is a two-person team rather than an individual. We use the dialogues between teammates to better understand the thought process underlying the emergence of cooperation. 

 

We find that teams learn to cooperate faster than individuals, and cooperation is more stable for teams. If we identify the strategies used by teams from their dialogues rather than using existing statistical methods based solely on their choices, the strategies identified from teams’ dialogues are simpler and less forward looking. Underlying this, teams typically do not form a complete strategy for an entire game, instead relying heavily on improvisation in the face of unexpected outcomes. Attempts at cooperation are primarily driven by teams unilaterally cooperating in the hope of inducing their opponent to cooperate.

 

Understanding how cooperation arises is important for many policy applications. For example, preventing collusion among firms is a major goal of anti-trust policy. Better understanding how such cooperation between firms arises is important for the better formulation of policies designed to prevent collusion and the resulting high prices for consumers. Work like ours changes economists’ understanding of how cooperation arises. Among other things, the improvisational nature of teams’ decision making suggests that they will be flexible in the fact of a changing environment, making it more difficult to disrupt collusion. Our work also emphasizes to the critical role of communication – in the absence of explicit communication, teams seek ways to implicitly send messages to their opponents. The focus of anti-trust policy on limiting explicit communication is well-founded, although regulators must understand that firms will seek other ways to communicate.

 

The other research funded by this grant explores similar themes. For example, “Learning and Contagion in Teams” studies how learning is affected by allowing teammates to switch rather than keeping fixed teams. We discover that learning is massively accelerated by switching teammates, as better performing teammates pass their insights on to their new teammates. This has important implications for the formation of workplace teams (don’t keep them the same!). Another paper, “Silence is Golden: Team Problem Solving and Communication Costs” looks at the effect on problem solving by teams if a small cost of communication is imposed on the team members. Counterintuitively, team performance improves when communication becomes more difficult. Message costs reduce the quantity of messages but increase the quality, specifically the mix of good and bad suggestions. The improved quality of communication with message costs allows teams to outperform individuals. Once again, this has clear implications for the functioning of workplace teams.

 

To summarize, the work funded by this grant illustrates the importance of studying decision making by groups. Teams often make different choices than individuals, team dialogues provide insights into why decisions are made, and varying the environment in which teams make decisions helps us understand how to make workplace teams as productive as possible.
